House Bill/Resolution NO. HB04498
FULL TITLE : AN ACT TO FURTHER PROMOTE ENTREPRENEURSHIP BY STRENGTHENING, EMPOWERING AND ENHANCING THE FINANCING PROGRAMS FOR MICRO, SMALL AND MEDIUM ENTERPRISES, AMENDING FOR THE PURPOSE OF REPUBLIC ACT NO. 6977, AS AMENDED, OTHERWISE KNOWN AS THE MAGNA CARTA FOR SMALL ENTERPRISES" AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES
PRINCIPAL AUTHOR/S : RODRIGUEZ, MAXIMO JR.B.
DATE FILED : 2016-11-23
SIGNIFICANCE: NATIONAL
CO-AUTHORS (Journal Entries) :
1. Sy-Alvarado (076 2017-02-28)2. Unabia (026 2017-09-19)
3. Belmonte (R.) (000 2018-01-18)4. Zarate (000 2018-01-18)
5. Nieto (000 2018-11-29)
ACTIONS TAKEN BY THE COMMITTEE
COMMITEE HEARINGS/ACTIONS:
      1. Referred to the Technical Working Group (TWG) on 2017-05-29
          -The Committee approved to subject HB 4498 to a TWG, with Rep. Jose Enrique Garcia III as chair, and the following as members: Reps. Rodriguez, Limkaichong, Rodrigo Abellanosa, Acosta, Juliette Uy and Alexandria Gonzales. Ms. Roman-Tayag requested that they be invited to the TWG to be able to share the BSP’s experience in the crafting of the legislative measure. The Committee likewise approved to consolidate House Bill No. 5540, introduced by Reps. Michael Romero and Enrico Pineda, with HB 4498 because among its provisions are the increase in capitalization of the SB Corp. and the mandatory allocation of credit resources to small enterprises, which are also stipulated in HB 4498, and can likewise be considered as amendments to the Magna Carta for MSMEs.
      2. Deliberated by the TWG on 2017-08-08
          -The TWG tackled Sections 1-18 of HB 4498 and the corresponding sections of HB 5540. Among the matters discussed and agreed upon during the meeting were: 1. Renaming of the MSME Centers to MSME Assistance Centers, MSME Negosyo Centers or simply Negosyo Centers; 2. Inclusion in the Advisory Unit of the Cooperative Development Authority (CDA) and a representative of a “National Organization” representing and dominated by MSMEs; 3. BSP to submit its position on the deletion of the phrase “subject to compliance with the rules and regulations to be issued by the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas and the Securities and Exchange Commission” in the second paragraph of Section 11-B of the Magna Carta for MSMEs, as proposed in HB 4498; 4. DBM to submit its official position on the funding provisions as well as the rules for the effective implementation of a share of eligible MSMEs of at least ten percent (10%) of total procurement value of goods and services supplied to the national government, its bureaus, offices and agencies; 5. GSIS to submit its official position on the bills, and also on its membership in the Board of Directors of the SB Corp., as suggested during the meeting; 6. Request of GSIS Vice President for Legal Affairs Group, Mr. Lucio Yu, and SSS Legislative Affairs Department Head, Atty. Joseph De Sunia, that they be exempted from the additional contribution to the additional capital stock of SB Corp., in view of the fiduciary obligation of the said agencies to defray the pensions and benefits of their members; 7. Reservation of PNB Vice President, Mr. Victor Calma, on the additional funding considering that PNB is no longer a government bank; 8. Request for PNB and SSS to reconsider their positions on the proposed contribution in the form of equity investments in common stock in the amount of Two Hundred Million pesos (P200,000,000.00), as proposed in HB 5540; 9. LBP and PNB to submit a report on their contribution in the form of equity investments in common stock in the amount of Two Hundred Million pesos (P200,000,000.00), as provided for in RA 6977; 10. SSS to submit its position on its membership in the Board of Directors of the SB Corp., as suggested during the meeting; and 11. SB Corp. to submit a report on the dividends it has paid to its stockholders. The Committee likewise agreed to seek the comments of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) on the bills and to invite them to the next TWG meeting scheduled on August 23, 2017 (Wednesday), at 9:30 A.M., at Room 5, Ramon V. Mitra Bldg.
      3. Deliberated by the TWG on 2017-08-29
          -The Technical Working Group (TWG), chaired by the Honorable Jose Enrique Garcia III, conducted its second meeting on House Bill No. 4498, introduced by Rep. Maximo Rodriguez, Jr., and House Bill No. 5540, introduced by Reps. Michael Romero and Enrico Pineda, which seek to amend the Magna Carta for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). The TWG first reviewed the substitute bill for the two bills which was prepared by the Secretariat, based on the discussions and agreements arrived at during the 1st TWG meeting on August 8, 2017. Rep. Garcia stated that some of the sections had to be revisited as the same have not been finalized yet. 1) The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) obliged to submit its official position on the funding provisions of the bills, and likewise on its formulation of the rules for the effective implementation of the entitlement of the MSMEs to at least 10% of the total procurement value of goods and services supplied to the government; 2) The TWG approved renaming the MSME Centers to MSME Negosyo Centers; 3) On their proposed membership in the Board of the Small Business Corporation (SB Corp.): • The Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) had no objection; • Atty. Joseph De Sunia of the Social Security System (SSS) said that the agency’s official comment will be submitted by September 6, 2017; 4) Rep. Enrico Pineda agreed to one (1) re-appointment for the Board of the SB Corp., and functioning on a hold-over capacity of the incumbent directors; 5) On the proposed deletion in the 2nd paragraph of Section 11-B of the law of the phrase “subject to compliance with the rules and regulations to be issued by the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)”, Ms. Tayag of BSP pointed out the importance of putting in place the financial accountability of SB Corp. She informed the body that they are finalizing their comments which will be sent to the TWG within the week. 6) On the proposed additional capitalization and funding of the SB Corp.: • DBM will submit its official comment on September 6, 2017. Ms. Brillantes of the DBM raised the agency’s objection to the additional paid-in capital to be provided the SB Corp. • GSIS and SSS will submit their official comments. The TWG then deliberated on the remaining Sections 18 to 25 of HB 4498 and the corresponding sections of HB 5540. Among the discussions and agreements were: 1) Deleted the allocation of at least twenty percent (20%) of the Conditional Cash Transfer (CCT) to be used as the livelihood component of the fund, upon the suggestion of Rep. Jocelyn Limkaichong, in view of the Pondo sa Pagbabago at Pag-asenso (P3) Fund to be provided the SB Corp., which was already approved by the Committee; 2) The Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) will submit its official comments on HB 4498, together with the following information: • Amounts allocated for the CCT and the Sustainable Livelihood Program (SLP); • % utilization of the SLP budget; • List of beneficiaries of the SLP; and • Success stories for the SLP. 3) Extended to another ten (10) years the implementation of the mandatory allocation of credit resources to MSMEs, as stipulated in the law; 4) Increased the penalties for non-compliance of the banks with the mandatory lending; and 5) Approved the submission of the MSMED Council to Congress of an annual report on the status and utilization of the penalties. The agencies were requested to submit the required reports and comments by September 6, 2017 to enable the Secretariat to input the same in the substitute bill, which will be emailed to the participants on September 11, 2017. The TWG participants will submit their feedback on the substitute bill on September 14, 2017. The final substitute bill will be presented to the Mother Committee, for its consideration and approval.
      4. Recommendations submitted by the TWG on 2017-09-26
          -Committee Chairman Peter Unabia underscored one salient provision of the Magna Carta for MSMEs, which is the mandatory allocation of credit resources for MSMEs, wherein at least 8% of the loan portfolio of all lending institutions shall be allocated for micro and small enterprises, and at least 2% for medium enterprises for a period of 10 years from the date of the effectivity of RA 9501. The said mandatory lending will expire in June 2018, thus the need to extend the same. Rep. Jose Enrique Garcia III presented the report of the Technical Working Group (TWG) which met on August 8 and 29, 2017 to consolidate and fine-tune the provisions of the subject bills. He discussed the amendments to the law, as contained in the draft substitute bill, among which are: 1. Inclusion of the Secretary of Finance in the MSMED Council; 2. Inclusion of the President of the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS) in the Board of the Small Business Corporation (SB Corp.); 3. Exclusion of grants and subsidies in the financial assistance to be extended by the SB Corp.; 4. Submission by the SB Corp. of a regular accountable report on the performance and financial condition of the Corporation; 5. Exemption of SB Corp. from securing prior BSP authorization for engaging in quasi-banking activities; 6. Provision by the National Government (NG), through the Department of Budget and Management (DBM), of additional paid-in capital to SB Corp. in the amount of at least P3 Billion within one (1) year and additional equities of P1 Billion a year thereafter for the next three (3) years; 7. Additional authorized capital stock of P2 Billion, of which P1 Billion will be established from a pool of funds to be contributed by the Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP), Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP), GSIS and Social Security System (SSS); 8. Extension to another ten (10) years of the mandatory allocation of credit resources for MSMEs; 9. Increase in the penalties for non-compliance with the mandatory lending; and 10. Submission by the MSMED Council to the Congress of the Philippines of an annual report on the status of the penalties remitted and the utilization thereof. The Committee agreed on the following amendments to the draft substitute bill: 1. Inclusion of the President of the SSS in the Board of the SB Corp.; 2. The financial assistance to be extended by the SB Corp. will not preclude retail lending in areas where private banks are not able to serve; 3. In view of requests by LBP, DBP, SSS and GSIS for exclusion from the contribution to the capital stock of the SB Corp., the additional capital contribution of SB Corp. in the amount of P1 Billion shall be allocated from the dividends remitted by LBP and DBP in the amount of P500 Million each. The Committee deferred approval of the substitute bill, pending the submission by the DBM of its official position paper, and review of the Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR) on the penal provisions of the law.
          -Presentation of the Draft Substitute Bill on House Bill No. 4498, introduced by Rep. Maximo B. Rodriguez, Jr., and House Bill No. 5540, introduced by Reps. Michael L. Romero and Enrico A. Pineda, re: Amendments to the Magna Carta for MSMEs
      5. Recommendations submitted by the TWG on 2017-11-27
          -Committee Chairman Peter Unabia stated that the approval of the substitute bill, which was reported out by the Technical Working Group (TWG), was deferred during the last committee meeting held on September 26, 2017 for the following reasons: 1. Awaiting submission of the position paper of the Department of Budget and Management (DBM). 2. Further review of the Penal Provisions of the proposed substitute bill, together with the IRR of the law on the sanctions. In its unofficial position on the bill, the DBM representative, Assistant Secretary Grace delos Santos, stated that: 1. The national government should not incur additional costs for the establishment of a guarantee system for distressed enterprises; 2. The amount and timeframe in the proposed bill to fully finance the authorized capital of Small Business Corporation (SB Corp.) is not economically practical or efficient stating that the funds may be utilized for other priority programs and projects. The provision of funds for the needs of the MSME sector must be viewed with an expanded timeframe. 3. Interposed no objection to the establishment of a P500 million Venture Capital Fund, however there is no separate implementing guidelines and selection criteria that must be set-up on the grant of the seed fund. A portion of the income generated from the interest of loans under the SB Corp.’s Pondo sa Pagbabago and Pag-Asenso program should be allocated as Venture Capital Fund. 4. The Committee should request for the comments of the Government Commission for GOCCs (GCG), and the Department of Finance (DOF) with regard to the capitalization requirements of the SB Corp. In summary, the DBM is constrained from favorably endorsing the proposed bill in its present form. In reaction, Chairman Unabi requested the DBM to review its position, considering President Duterte’s pronouncement in the recent ASEAN Economic Summit that his administration will strongly support MSMEs, believing that they are the driving force for economic development. Reps. Jose Enrique Garcia III and Jocelyn S. Limkaichong echoed the President’s statement that he will review the budget and increase the allocation for MSMEs. The Committee approved the following additional amendments to the bill: 1. Delete the phrase “in the amount of Five Hundred Million Pesos (P500,000,000.00)” as itemized contribution by the Land Bank of the Philippines (LBP) and the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP); and 2. Define the term “smaller banks”, with the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) tasked to craft the language. This is to categorize and differentiate middle banks from small banks and thrift banks. The Committee approved the substitute bill, subject to amendments, with all the members present even in the past meetings thereon, to be included as co-authors.
          -Consideration and Approval of the Draft Substitute Bill on House Bill No. 4498, introduced by Rep. Maximo B. Rodriguez, Jr., and House Bill No. 5540, introduced by Reps. Michael L. Romero and Enrico A. Pineda, re: Amendments to the Magna Carta for MSMEs
      6. Measure approved by the Committee on 2018-09-25
          -Philippine Export Confederation, Inc. (PhilExport) and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) proposed amendments to the substitute bill, which were approved by the Committee. The Committee approved the substitute bill to House Bills Numbered 4498 and 5540, as amended, subject to style. Chairman Laogan directed the Secretariat to finalize to the substitute bill; follow-up with the Committee on Appropriations on its action on the funding provisions of the substitute bill; and, after approval by the Committee on Appropriations, to prepare and file the appropriate Committee Report.
      7. Other Action by the Committee on Rules on 2018-12-11
          -1. On Page 5, Lines 27 to 29, the phrase “in coordination with the microfinance NGO Regulatory Council” was deleted, as suggested by DTI-BMSMED Asst. Director Alice Opeña, because of the existence of other councils which the MSMED Council can coordinate with on the matter of the provision of training, development programs and consultation; 2. On Page 7, Line 15, the President of the Social Security System was included as a Member of the Board of Directors of SB Corp. 3. On Page 8, Lines 16 to 19, after much discussion, the body agreed to insert the phrase “and not to preclude retail lending in areas where private banks are not able to serve, subject to consultation with the private banks” in the forms of financial assistance which can be extended by the SB Corp. 4. On Page 10, lines 20 to 36, up to page 11, lines 1 to 3, likewise after much debate and discussion, the additional authorized capital stock of P2B, of which P1B will be established from a pool of funds to be contributed in the form of equity investments in the form of common stock by the Land Bank of the Philippines and the Development Bank of the Philippines, and in preferred stocks by the SSS and the GSIS has been replaced with an additional capital contribution of P1B to be allocated by the DBM from the dividends remitted by the LBP and the DBP in the amount of P500M each. The Committee likewise agreed that the SSS and the GSIS shall continue to support MSMEs and shall continue to sit in the Board. 5. On page 11, lines 8 to 9, inserted the phrase “and in general to guarantee lending by private banks to MSMEs,” to the provision on the set-up of a guarantee fund as a mechanism for bankruptcy preventive measures and mutual relief system for distressed enterprises, as suggested by SB Corp. President Ma. Luna Cacanando, in order to augment the guarantee fund of SB Corp. to support lending of private banks to MSMEs; 6. On page 12, lines 26 to 29, the provision on not requiring SB Corp. to secure a Quasi-banking license from the BSP was reworded. 7. Revised Line 17 of Page 13, stating that the annual report to be submitted by the BSP to the MSMED Council on the banks’ compliance and non-compliance shall be signed by the appropriate officer instead of by the appropriate compliance officer; and 8. On page 14, lines 10 to 11, replaced the phrase “amount of noncompliance” with the phrase “level of compliance.”
